title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is a new law that aims to provide viewpoint protection in communications. It amends Title I of the Communications Act of 1934 to include a section on viewpoint protection. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the revocation of licenses or other actions based on viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. It also prohibits placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews. This law does not affect the Commission's authority to take action for violations of specific laws. The Commission can take action or impose conditions on approvals for violations of specific laws, public interest obligations, or dissemination of content. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcasted content. Additionally, the President cannot impose conditions on approvals or decisions related to the viewpoints expressed in broadcasted content. The President cannot direct agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints in broadcasted content. This subsection does not affect the President's authority to take action on violations of specific laws related to content dissemination. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their broadcasted content, including incitement under the First Amendment. This does not limit the President's ability to enforce specific laws related to content dissemination. The term "agency" in this subsection refers to its definition in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
